title: Giant's kettle
text:
A giant's kettle, also known as either a giant's cauldron, moulin pothole, or glacial pothole, is a typically large and cylindrical <a href="Pothole%20%28landform%29">pothole</a> <a href="drilling">drilled</a> in solid <a href="rock%20%28geology%29">rock</a> underlying a glacier either by water descending down a deep <a href="Moulin%20%28geomorphology%29">moulin</a> or by <a href="gravel">gravel</a> rotating in the bed of <a href="Subglacial%20stream">subglacial meltwater stream</a>.
The interiors of potholes tend to be smooth and regular, unlike a <a href="plunge%20pool">plunge pool</a>. An example is the large pothole found in <a href="Archbald%2C%20Pennsylvania">Archbald, Pennsylvania</a>, in <a href="Archbald%20Pothole%20State%20Park">Archbald Pothole State Park</a>.
Formation.
Giant's kettles are formed while a <a href="bedrock">bedrock</a> surface is covered by a glacier. Water, produced by the thawing of the <a href="ice">ice</a> and <a href="snow">snow</a>, forms <a href="stream">stream</a>s on the surface of the glacier, which, having gathered into their courses a certain amount of <a href="Moraine">morainic</a> debris, finally flow down a <a href="crevasse">crevasse</a> as a swirling <a href="waterfall">cascade</a> or <a href="Moulin%20%28geomorphology%29">moulin</a>. The sides of the crevasse are abraded, and a vertical shaft is formed in the ice. The <a href="erosion">erosion</a> may be continued into the bed of the glacier; and, the ice having left the district, the giant's kettle so formed is seen as an empty shaft, or as a <a href="Plumbing">pipe</a> filled with gravel, <a href="sand">sand</a>, or <a href="boulder">boulder</a>s. Such cavities and pipes afford valuable evidence as to the former extent of glaciers.
Similar potholes are encountered in <a href="stream%20bed">riverbed</a>s and the <a href="Channeled%20Scablands">Channeled Scablands</a> scoured by glacial <a href="outburst%20flood">outburst flood</a>s.
Notable giant's kettle.
The GletscherGarten of <a href="Lucerne">Lucerne</a> (<a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>) is famous for its giant's kettles, having 32 in number, the largest being wide and deep. They are also common in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> ("gletschertopf"; <a href="glacier">glacier</a> <a href="Stock%20pot">pot</a>), <a href="Norway">Norway</a> ("jettegryte"), <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> ("jättegryta"), <a href="Finland">Finland</a> ("hiidenkirnu"; <a href="hiisi">hiisi</a>'s <a href="Butter%20churn">churn</a>), and <a href="Moss%20Island">Moss Island</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
